docs.title: lbx - Lock Box
docs.text: A lightweight secret storage vault with CLI and Python API. Stores secrets in encrypted files with master password secured via OS keychain.

docs.title: What is lbx?
docs.text: lbx provides secure, encrypted storage for sensitive data like API keys, passwords, and configuration secrets. It features both a command-line interface and Python API for seamless integration into your workflow.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Secure Encryption: AES-256 encryption with master password protection
  • Cross-Platform: Works on Windows, macOS, and Linux
  • Dual Interface: Both CLI and Python API available
  • Keychain Integration: Master password stored securely in OS keychain
  • Simple Workflow: Intuitive commands for daily use
  • Minimal Dependencies: Lightweight and secure

docs.title: lbx
docs.text:
Public Lbx API exposure.

This module re-exports the high-level Lbx vault manager so users can import it directly from :mod:lbx rather than navigating internal packages. The internal structure remains hidden; only stable API surfaces are exposed here.

docs.title: Lbx
docs.text:
Lbx(
    path: Path | str | None = None,
    *,
    use_keychain: bool = True,
    binary_service: BinaryService | None = None,
    file_service: FileService | None = None,
    keyring_service: KeyringService | None = None,
    crypto_service: CryptoService | None = None,
)

High-level vault manager.

This class provides the main API for working with an Lbx vault: creating, unlocking, locking, deleting, and managing services and secrets. It composes the service layer into a single cohesive interface.

By default, the derived encryption key is stored in the OS keychain whenever a vault is created or unlocked. This can be controlled via the use_keychain flag.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default path Path | str | None

Optional path to the vault file. If None, the default vault path (as determined by FileService) is used.

None use_keychain bool

Whether to store the derived encryption key in the OS keychain when creating or unlocking the vault.

True binary_service BinaryService | None

Optional preconfigured BinaryService instance.

None file_service FileService | None

Optional preconfigured FileService instance.

None keyring_service KeyringService | None

Optional preconfigured KeyringService instance.

None crypto_service CryptoService | None

Optional preconfigured CryptoService instance.

None

Unlock an existing vault using a password.

This method:

  • Loads the vault from disk.
  • Verifies the password against the stored master key.
  • Derives and sets the encryption key.
  • Stores the encryption key in the OS keychain if use_keychain is True.

If the vault file does not exist.

Unlock the vault using the OS keychain.

This method attempts to:

Vault file is truncated or structurally inconsistent.

This indicates that the file appears to be an Lbx vault (magic matches) but internal structure or lengths are invalid.

Common causes
  • Length-prefixed blocks exceed available bytes.
  • Reads attempt to go past the end of the buffer.
  • Sections are incomplete or malformed.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to lbx. We welcome contributions of all kinds — bug reports, documentation improvements, feature requests, and code contributions.

docs.title: Ways to Contribute
docs.text:
Reporting Issues: Open an issue with detailed steps to reproduce, expected behavior, and environment details.

Documentation: Fix typos, add examples, improve clarity, or enhance API documentation.

Code: Submit bug fixes, new features, performance improvements, or test coverage enhancements.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Git installed and configured
  • Python 3.10+ installed
  • Nox for task automation: pipx install nox
  • GitHub workflow familiarity

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Fork on GitHub, then:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/lbx.git
cd lbx
nox -s devenv-3.13  # Setup environment
nox                 # Verify setup

See Development Setup for detailed instructions.

docs.title: 1. Fork and Clone
docs.text:
Fork the repository on GitHub, then clone your fork:

git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/lbx.git
cd lbx

docs.title: 2. Create a Branch
docs.text:
Create a descriptive branch for your changes:

git checkout -b feat/add-export-command
git checkout -b fix/memory-leak-issue-123
git checkout -b docs/improve-installation-guide

Branch naming conventions:

Prefix Purpose Example feat/ New features feat/async-support fix/ Bug fixes fix/validation-error docs/ Documentation docs/api-reference refactor/ Code refactoring refactor/simplify-parser test/ Test improvements test/add-integration-tests chore/ Maintenance chore/update-dependencies

docs.title: 3. Make Your Changes
docs.text:
Follow the code standards and ensure:

  • Code is properly formatted and linted
  • Type hints are included for public APIs
  • Tests are added or updated
  • Documentation is updated if needed

docs.title: 4. Add Changelog Entry
docs.text:
For user-facing changes, add a changelog fragment:

# Format: changelog.d/<number>.<type>.md
changelog.d/123.added.md      # New feature
changelog.d/456.fixed.md      # Bug fix
changelog.d/789.changed.md    # Behavior change

Skip for: Documentation, internal refactoring, CI updates, typos (add no-changelog label).

docs.title: 5. Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
Use Conventional Commits format:

# Format: <type>(<scope>): <description>

git commit -m "feat(cli): add export command with JSON support"
git commit -m "fix(core): resolve memory leak in encryption module"
git commit -m "docs: update installation instructions"
git commit -m "test: add integration tests for vault operations"

Commit types:

  • feat: New feature
  • fix: Bug fix
  • docs: Documentation changes
  • test: Test additions or modifications
  • refactor: Code refactoring
  • perf: Performance improvements
  • chore: Maintenance tasks
  • ci: CI/CD changes

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, ensure you have:

  • Git: Version control (Download)
  • Python: Version 3.10 or higher (Download)
  • Nox: Task automation tool

Install Nox:

pipx (Recommended)pip 
python -m pip install --user pipx
python -m pipx ensurepath

docs.text:
Fork the repository on GitHub, then clone your fork:

git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/lbx.git
cd lbx

docs.title: 2. Add Upstream Remote
docs.text:
Add the original repository as upstream:

git remote add upstream https://github.com/jd-35656/lbx.git

docs.title: 3. Create Development Environment
docs.text:
Use Nox to set up a complete development environment:

nox -s devenv-3.13

This creates a virtual environment in .nox/devenv-3-13/ with:

  • Project installed in editable mode
  • All test dependencies
  • Type checking tools
  • Documentation tools
  • Development utilities

Unix/Linux/macOSWindows

nox                     # Run all checks

docs.title: Switching Python Versions

The project supports Python 3.10 through 3.13. Use different environments for each version:

# List available sessions

source .nox/devenv-3-12/bin/activate

# Install pyenv (macOS)
brew install pyenv

# Install Python versions
pyenv install 3.10.13
pyenv install 3.11.7
pyenv install 3.12.1

pyenv local 3.13.0 3.12.1 3.11.7 3.10.13

docs.title: Releasing
docs.text: This guide covers the release process for maintainers and contributors with release permissions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Releases are automated through GitHub Actions. The workflow handles version bumping, changelog generation, Git tagging, PyPI publishing, and documentation deployment.

flowchart LR
    A[Trigger Release] --> B[Calculate Version]
    B --> C[Generate Changelog]
    C --> D[Commit & Tag]
    D --> E[Create GitHub Release]
    E --> F[Publish to PyPI]
    F --> G[Deploy Docs]

docs.title: Triggering a Release
docs.text:
GitHub Actions (Recommended)PR Labels
  1. Navigate to Actions → Create Release
  2. Click Run workflow
  3. Select the release type (patch, minor, or major)
  4. Click Run workflow to start

When to Use

Best for scheduled releases or when you need full control over timing.

Add one of these labels to a PR before merging:

  • release:patch — Bug fixes only
  • release:minor — New features (backward-compatible)
  • release:major — Breaking changes

The release triggers automatically after the PR merges to main.

When to Use

Best for feature releases tied to specific PRs.

docs.title: Release Types
docs.text:
Type Version Change Use Case patch 1.0.0 → 1.0.1 Bug fixes, security patches, documentation fixes minor 1.0.0 → 1.1.0 New features, deprecations, non-breaking changes major 1.0.0 → 2.0.0 Breaking API changes, major refactors

Versioning Standard

This project follows Semantic Versioning 2.0.0.

docs.title: Pre-Release Checklist
docs.text:
Before triggering a release, verify:

  • All CI checks pass on main
  • Branch is up to date with no pending critical PRs
  • Changelog fragments exist in changelog.d/ (or PR has no-changelog label)
  • No blocking issues in the milestone
  • Dependencies are up to date (if applicable)
# Verify changelog fragments exist
ls changelog.d/*.md

# Preview the changelog (optional)
nox -s changelog -- --draft

docs.title: Automated Workflow Steps
docs.text:
When a release is triggered, the following happens automatically:

Step Action Tool/Service 1 Calculate next version GitHub Actions 2 Generate changelog from fragments Towncrier 3 Update CHANGELOG.md Towncrier 4 Bump version in pyproject.toml Automated script 5 Commit changes Git 6 Create Git tag Git 7 Push to main Git 8 Create GitHub Release GitHub API 9 Build distribution hatch build 10 Publish to PyPI pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish 11 Deploy documentation GitHub Pages

docs.title: Changelog Fragments
docs.text: Each user-facing change requires a changelog fragment in changelog.d/.

docs.title: Fragment Format
docs.text: changelog.d/<issue-or-pr-number>.<type>.md

docs.title: Fragment Types
docs.text: Type Description Example .security Security vulnerability fixes 215.security.md .removed Removed features 201.removed.md .deprecated Soon-to-be removed features 189.deprecated.md .added New features or functionality 142.added.md .changed Changes to existing functionality 178.changed.md .fixed Bug fixes 156.fixed.md

docs.title: Example Fragment
docs.text:
<!-- changelog.d/142.added.md -->
Added support for async context managers in `Client` class.

Skip Changelog

For changes that don't need changelog entries (typos, CI tweaks), add the no-changelog label to the PR

docs.title: Post-Release Verification
docs.text:
After a release completes:

  1. Verify PyPI: Check PyPI project page for the new version
  2. Verify GitHub Release: Confirm release notes are accurate
  3. Verify Docs: Check live documentation reflects changes
  4. Test Installation:
pip install lbx==X.Y.Z

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text: Problem Cause Solution Release workflow fails CI checks failing Fix failing tests, re-run workflow PyPI upload fails Version already exists Ensure version was bumped correctly PyPI upload fails Invalid token Verify PYPI_API_TOKEN secret Empty changelog No fragments found Add fragments or use no-changelog Docs not updating Deploy step failed Check gh-pages branch and workflow logs Tag already exists Previous failed release Delete tag and retry

docs.title: Manual Recovery
docs.text:
If the automated release fails partway through:

# Check current state
git fetch --tags
git log --oneline -5

# If tag was created but release failed, delete and retry
git tag -d vX.Y.Z
git push origin :refs/tags/vX.Y.Z

docs.title: Hotfix Releases
docs.text:
For critical bugs in production:

  1. Create a hotfix branch from the release tag:
git checkout -b hotfix/issue-description vX.Y.Z

  1. Apply the fix and add a changelog fragment

  2. Open a PR to main

  3. After merge, trigger a patch release immediately

docs.title: Rollback Procedures
docs.text:
Use with Caution

Only roll back if the release causes critical issues.

Manual Process Required

Since releases are automated via GitHub Actions, rollbacks must be performed manually.

docs.title: Yank from PyPI (Soft Rollback)
docs.text:
Prevents new installations but doesn't remove existing ones:

Via PyPI Web Interface (Only method available):

  • Go to PyPI project page
  • Navigate to Releases → Select version → Options → Yank
  • Add reason for yanking

docs.title: Full Rollback
docs.text:
1. Yank the release from PyPI (see above)
  2. Update GitHub Release with warning banner
  3. Create hotfix release with the fix
  4. Communicate with users via GitHub Discussions or issues

docs.title: Required Secrets
docs.text:
Configure these in Settings → Secrets and variables → Actions:

Secret Purpose How to Obtain PYPI_API_TOKEN PyPI publishing PyPI API tokens

Trusted Publishers

Consider using PyPI Trusted Publishers instead of API tokens for improved security.

docs.title: Key Files
docs.text: File Purpose .github/workflows/ci.yml CI checks and tests workflow .github/workflows/release.yml Release automation workflow pyproject.toml Project metadata and version changelog.d/ Changelog fragments directory docs/changelog.md Generated changelog towncrier.toml Towncrier configuration

docs.title: Useful Commands
docs.text:
# Preview changelog without making changes
nox -s changelog -- --draft

# Build distribution locally
hatch build

# Deploy docs manually (if needed)
nox -s docs_deploy

docs.text:
Optional Section

Include if you have a regular release cadence.

Release Type Frequency Day Minor Quarterly First Monday Patch As needed Any day Major As needed With announcement

docs.title: Testing
docs.text: Complete guide for running tests, ensuring code quality, and validating changes before submitting contributions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This project uses Nox to automate testing across multiple Python versions. All test sessions include code coverage reporting and enforce a minimum 90% coverage threshold.

Supported Python Versions: 3.10, 3.11, 3.12, 3.13

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Run tests and quality checks (default)
nox

# Run tests on specific Python version
nox -s tests-3.13

# Run all quality checks
nox -s check

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
All VersionsSpecific VersionCurrent Python 
nox -s tests

nox -s tests-3.13
nox -s tests-3.10

nox --python current -s tests

docs.title: Passing Arguments to Pytest
docs.text:
Pass custom arguments to pytest using --:

# Verbose output
nox -s tests-3.13 -- -v

# Run specific test file
nox -s tests-3.13 -- tests/test_cli.py

# Run tests matching pattern
nox -s tests-3.13 -- -k test_encryption

# Stop on first failure
nox -s tests-3.13 -- -x

# Multiple arguments
nox -s tests-3.13 -- -v -x --tb=short

docs.title: Common Pytest Options
docs.text: Option Description -v, --verbose Increase verbosity -s Disable output capturing (show print statements) -x, --exitfirst Stop on first test failure -k EXPRESSION Run tests matching given expression --lf, --last-failed Rerun only tests that failed last time --ff, --failed-first Run failed tests first, then others --maxfail=N Stop after N failures --tb=short Shorter traceback format --tb=no Disable traceback --pdb Drop into debugger on failure

docs.title: Viewing Coverage Reports
docs.text:
Test sessions automatically generate coverage reports:

nox -s tests-3.13

Terminal Output:

---------- coverage: platform darwin, python 3.13.0 -----------
Name                    Stmts   Miss  Cover   Missing
-----------------------------------------------------
src/lbx/__init__.py      12      0   100%
src/lbx/core.py         145      7    95%   78-82, 156
src/lbx/cli.py           89      4    96%   234-237
-----------------------------------------------------
TOTAL                     246     11    96%

Required test coverage of 90% reached. Total coverage: 96.00%

docs.title: HTML Coverage Reports
docs.text:
Generate interactive HTML coverage report:

nox -s tests-3.13 -- --cov-report=html

View the report:

# macOS
open htmlcov/index.html

# Linux
xdg-open htmlcov/index.html

# Windows
start htmlcov/index.html

docs.title: Coverage Requirements
docs.text:
From pyproject.toml:

[tool.coverage.report]
fail_under = 90
show_missing = true
exclude_lines = [
    "pragma: no cover",
    "if __name__ == .__main__.:",
    "if TYPE_CHECKING:",
]

Minimum Threshold

All code must maintain at least 90% test coverage. Tests will fail if coverage drops below this threshold.

docs.title: Linting
docs.text:
Check code style and formatting with Ruff:

nox -s lint

This validates:

  • Code style compliance (PEP 8)
  • Import sorting and organization
  • Unused imports and variables
  • Security issues (via Bandit rules)
  • Code complexity
  • Common bugs and anti-patterns

Configuration: See [tool.ruff] section in pyproject.toml

docs.title: Type Checking
docs.text:
Run static type analysis with MyPy:

# Check all source files
nox -s typecheck

# Check specific module
nox -s typecheck -- src/lbx/core

# Check specific file
nox -s typecheck -- src/lbx/cli.py

Configuration: See [tool.mypy] section in pyproject.toml

docs.title: Combined Quality Checks
docs.text:
Run both linting and type checking:

nox -s check

This is equivalent to running:

nox -s lint
nox -s typecheck

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
Create a complete development environment:

nox -s devenv-3.13

This installs:

  • Project in editable mode
  • All test dependencies (pytest, pytest-cov)
  • Type checking tools (mypy)
  • Documentation dependencies
  • Development tools (nox)

docs.title: Activating the Environment
docs.text:
# Unix/Linux/macOS
source .nox/devenv-3-13/bin/activate

# Windows
.nox\devenv-3-13\Scripts\activate

docs.title: IDE Configuration
docs.text:
Configure your IDE to use the Nox virtual environment:

# Get Python interpreter path (after activation)
which python

# Example output:
# /path/to/project/.nox/devenv-3-13/bin/python

Point your IDE's Python interpreter to this path.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
tests/
├── __init__.py
├── conftest.py              # Shared fixtures
├── test_core.py             # Core functionality tests
├── test_cli.py              # CLI tests
└── integration/
    └── test_e2e.py          # End-to-end tests

docs.title: Test Discovery
docs.text:
Pytest automatically discovers:

  • Test files: tests/test_*.py or tests/*_test.py
  • Test functions: def test_*()
  • Test classes: class Test*
  • Test methods: def test_*() within test classes

Configuration in pyproject.toml:

[tool.pytest.ini_options]
testpaths = ["tests"]
pythonpath = ["src"]

docs.title: Available Nox Sessions
docs.text:
View all available sessions:

nox --list

docs.title: Testing Sessions
docs.text: Session Description tests-3.10 Run tests on Python 3.10 tests-3.11 Run tests on Python 3.11 tests-3.12 Run tests on Python 3.12 tests-3.13 Run tests on Python 3.13

docs.title: Quality Sessions
docs.text: Session Description lint Run Ruff linter checks typecheck Run MyPy type checking check Run lint + typecheck

docs.title: Development Sessions
docs.text: Session Description devenv-3.X Set up development environment build Build distribution packages

docs.title: Documentation Sessions
docs.text: Session Description docs_serve Serve documentation locally deploy_docs Deploy docs to GitHub Pages

docs.title: Continuous Integration
docs.text:
All pull requests must pass:

  • Tests on all supported Python versions (3.10-3.13)
  • Code coverage threshold (≥90%)
  • Linting checks (Ruff)
  • Type checking (MyPy)

docs.title: Running CI Checks Locally
docs.text:
Before pushing changes:

# Run default sessions (tests + check)
nox

# Run tests on all Python versions
nox -s tests

# Verify code quality
nox -s check

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text: Problem Solution Nox not found Install: pip install nox or pipx install nox Python version unavailable Install missing version or use --python current Import errors during tests Install project: pip install -e . or run nox -s devenv Coverage below threshold Add tests or mark unreachable code with # pragma: no cover Port 8000 already in use Kill process: lsof -ti :8000 \| xargs kill -9

docs.title: Clearing Nox Cache
docs.text:
Remove all virtual environments:

nox --clean

Remove specific session:

rm -rf .nox/tests-3-13

docs.title: Verbose Output
docs.text:
See all commands executed by Nox:

nox -s tests-3.13 --verbose

docs.title: Pre-Commit Checklist
docs.text:
• All tests pass locally
  • Code coverage ≥90%
  • Linting passes
  • Type checking passes
  • Documentation updated
  • Changelog fragment added

docs.title: Testing Workflow
docs.text:
# Setup (once)
nox -s devenv-3.13
source .nox/devenv-3-13/bin/activate

# Development
pytest tests/test_core.py -v

# Pre-commit
nox -s tests-3.13 check

# Pre-push
nox

docs.title: Writing Tests
docs.text:
# tests/test_example.py
import pytest


def test_basic_functionality():
    """Test basic feature behavior."""
    result = my_function(input_data)
    assert result == expected_output


def test_error_handling():
    """Test that errors are raised appropriately."""
    with pytest.raises(ValueError, match="Invalid input"):
        my_function(invalid_data)


@pytest.mark.parametrize("input,expected", [
    (1, 2),
    (2, 4),
    (3, 6),
])
def test_multiple_cases(input, expected):
    """Test function with multiple inputs."""
    assert double(input) == expected

docs.title: Parallel Test Execution
docs.text:
Install pytest-xdist:

pip install pytest-xdist

Run tests in parallel:

# Use 4 workers
nox -s tests-3.13 -- -n 4

# Use auto-detection
nox -s tests-3.13 -- -n auto

docs.title: Test Reports
docs.text:
Generate JUnit XML report (for CI systems):

nox -s tests-3.13 -- --junit-xml=test-results.xml

docs.title: Debugging Tests
docs.text:
Drop into debugger on failure:

nox -s tests-3.13 -- --pdb

Show local variables in traceback:

nox -s tests-3.13 -- -l

docs.title: Rerunning Failed Tests
docs.text:
# Run only last failed tests
nox -s tests-3.13 -- --lf

# Run failed tests first, then remaining
nox -s tests-3.13 -- --ff

docs.title: Configuration Reference
docs.text:
All testing, coverage, and linting configurations are defined in pyproject.toml. See the file for:

  • Test discovery paths and options
  • Coverage thresholds and reporting
  • Code formatting rules
  • Linting and type checking settings

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Install lbx using your preferred Python package manager.

docs.title: Recommended: Using pipx
docs.text:
Why pipx?

pipx installs Python CLI tools in isolated environments, keeping your global Python setup clean while making the command available system-wide.

docs.title: Install pipx
docs.text:
macOSUbuntu / DebianWindows (Scoop)Windows (pip)Other Linux 
brew install pipx

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with lbx in minutes.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
pipx install lbx

See Installation Guide for other installation options.

docs.title: Create a new vault
docs.text:
lbx vault init

You'll be prompted for a password. The derived encryption key is stored in your OS keychain.

docs.title: Add a secret
docs.text:
lbx secret add github token --value ghp_xxxxxx

Or pipe it for better security:

printf "ghp_xxxxxx" | lbx secret add github token

docs.title: Retrieve a secret
docs.text:
lbx secret get github token

If the keychain key is missing or outdated, you'll be prompted for the password.

docs.title: Update a secret
docs.text: printf "new-value" | lbx secret update github token

docs.title: List services and secrets
docs.text:
lbx service list
lbx secret list
lbx secret list --service github

docs.title: Rename or move secrets
docs.text:
lbx secret rename github token api_key
lbx secret move github api_key gitlab

docs.title: Lock the vault
docs.text: lbx vault lock

docs.title: Delete the vault
docs.text: lbx vault delete

docs.title: Python API
docs.text:
from lbx import Lbx

# Load vault (auto-load key from keychain when available)
vault = Lbx()

vault.get_secret("github", "token")  # returns SecretEntry
vault.add_secret("github", "token", "new-value")
vault.list_services()
vault.list_secrets()
